title: If Statements (Making Decisions)

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: IF keyword followed by condition in parentheses. Condition must be true/false (boolean). If true, code in { } runs. If false, code skipped.
Curly braces contain code to run when condition is true. Can have 1 line or 100 lines. ALL code in braces runs together. ALWAYS use braces even for 1 line!
Double equals (==) checks if values are EQUAL. Single = assigns, double == compares! if (x == 5) checks equality. if (x = 5) is ERROR (assignment, not comparison).
Condition must evaluate to true or false. Can be: comparison (x > 5), variable (bool isReady), or method (text.Contains("hi")).

challenge.instructions:
Create a movie ticket price calculator!

1. Ask user for age
2. Ask for day of week ("weekday" or "weekend")
3. Set base price = 15
4. Apply discounts using IF statements:
   - IF age < 12: Child discount, price = 8
   - IF age >= 65: Senior discount, price = 10
   - IF day is "weekday": Reduce price by $3
5. Display final ticket price

Example:
Age: 10
Day: weekday
Child ticket: $8
Weekday discount: -$3
Final price: $5
challenge.hint: Use if (age < 12) for child. if (age >= 65) for senior. if (day == "weekday") for weekday. Remember == not = for comparison! Modify price variable inside each if.
commonStickingPoints: Using = instead of ==: if (x = 5) is WRONG! That's assignment. Use if (x == 5) for comparison. Very common beginner mistake!
Forgetting braces: if (x > 5) Console.WriteLine("Hi"); works but dangerous! Always use { }: if (x > 5) { Console.WriteLine("Hi"); } for clarity and safety.
Condition not boolean: if (5) is ERROR! Condition must be true/false. Must be: if (x == 5) or if (isReady) where isReady is bool.
Semicolon after if: if (x > 5); { code } is WRONG! Semicolon ends the if, so { code } always runs! No semicolon after if (condition).
